From: Zoom
Date: Sat, May 25, 2024 at 9:02 AM
Subject: Action Required - Zoom Phone License Notification
To:
Dear Valued Customer,
As an admin or owner of an account utilizing Zoom Phone, we are reaching
out to notify you that we have acknowledged the changes you have made to
the Phone licenses on your subscription. Our engineering team has
identified that some of your users may still be on your old calling plan.
In an effort to ensure you do not lose important user profile information,
we are allowing you 6 calendar days from the date of change, to make any
updates and ensure all your users are on an active plan. If you do not make
the changes within this period, the user profiles associated with your
originally assigned licenses will be lost. Please take advantage of this 6
days grace period. *At the end of the 6 days, the user profiles for the new
licenses on your account in your Admin portal will have to be reconfigured
in your Admin portal.*
If you do not make these updates, 6 calendar days from the date of change,
your users may lose some of their Zoom Phone privileges and key
functionalities.
If you need additional information, please reference our Support
page.

Hi Jennifer,
Thank you for the outreach. First, I wanted to clarify the email address you sent your email to - tns@powerhousearts.org. See below – were you trying to send this request to support? If so, it needs to go to support@thetnsgroup.com. If you send to the tns@ email address, our team will not get it.
In terms of backups – Powerhouse does not have onsite servers to hold data. The policy is for users to store files in Box. Powerhouse has a Business Plus plan and any backups/replications are through Box.
Please let me know if you need anything further. Thank you, Erika

In celebration of the upcoming Memorial Day holiday, please take note that Omega Systems' corporate offices will be closed on

Hi TNS and friends,
Hope you all are safe and well.
I'm reaching out because I have a few tech needs for my upcoming
Conversation Series program in April and I want to know what's the best way
to proceed with purchasing.
Initially, I was thinking that my dept. (Community Engagement and
Partnerships) could purchase the items and be responsible for safekeeping
and maintenance, but since it's looking like these items could be shared by
other depts. I'm wondering if it would be best to purchase through TNS.
This way our items would be insured and not our dept.'s individual
responsibility. What are your thoughts?
The items we are needing are listed below:
- 3 iPads
- Roland Aerocaster: https://proav.roland.com/global/products/aerocaster/
https://www.amazon.com/Roland-AeroCaster-Live-Streaming-System/dp/B09NXQ64M8

For our meeting, besides your standard agenda, please:
- take a scan through any emails for any questions or requests I've sent to support@tns or to your team; I will too.
- let me know any ideas you have about how we can do a better job of getting service requests resolved with fewer interactions and better closure?

I'm thinking of Megan, with her Aternal request, and the current salesforce login issue; and the business with "wifi at the gatehouse." I'm not saying TNS is doing anything wrong. In fact, I may have muddied the waters by getting involved. I'm saying I want consider what it takes to raise the bar.

Hello Erika & Team:
I'm plowing through emails and notes, and noticed this, from last month's TNS/Powerhouse status call:
Wi-Fi Project
Quote was sent for visibility purposes; TNS wanted to clarify the request and to ensure the cabling is in place should we move forward, prior to approval
It was agreed to delete this quote – we are not going forward at this time
When walking around, physical access points that unlock the doors are on Wi-Fi and some are responding slowly
there may be a desire to add access points
TNS was asked for additional coverage – 2 access points in the parking lot – they are not directly attached to the access system
Concern that Dan is getting pulled in different directions and we need to do some realignment
Any quote requests, TNS to walk away and alert to Steven or David so they can investigate further
Action:
David to speak to Mitch to clarify his askes for the 2 Access Points in the parking lot
I want to clarify and close the loop on this.
1. I have not yet met with Mitch, but I plan to this week.
2. Above, does the "Wi-Fi" project refer to the two AP's Mitch requested for the parking lot? Anything additional?
3. Did Mitch request the two APs in the parking lot because he expected that would fix the slow-responding doors, or is that separate?
Thanks
/dk

Erika
It was good meeting you yesterday! I can't tell you how many times that I've been intently focused on a conversation -- as we were yesterday -- and missed it when a new zoom participant showed up. Sorry that happened!
What's a good way to schedule time with you, generally?
If you have availability to speak Fri or Mon, name some times and I'll make that work. My general schedule is to be onsite at Powerhouse Tue-Thu.
I want to speak to you to understand the current relationship between Powerhouse and TNS; your observations about what's working and where there are challenges; your thoughts about how Powerhouse's needs are evolving; your input on any support you may desire from your own organization in order to serve Powerhouse in the best way.
If you haven't already, please share to my vcto@powerhousearts.org email address whatever contract or scope documents you think may be helpful. If you have monthly reports or critical incident reports, and it won't take more than an hour to put together, please send that my way too.

From: Pamela Rapp
Sent: Friday, February 2, 2024 3:16 PM
To: Robert Nieves ; Erika Ellis
Cc: David Koosis ; Daniel Lucas ; Pradeesh Padmasenan ; Iris Garcia
Subject: Fashion show Feb. 10 &11 same live streaming needs as September 10 & 11 2023
EXTERNAL EMAIL!!!
Hi Erika, Rob, Daniel,
I am reaching out because we have another large Fashion show with the same group / client as last September coming up.
The requirements for the internet service provided by the venue are the same and are in detail the following:
The internet connection must be provided through an ethernet cable positioned near the video control room.
The connection must be at least 30 Mbps in upload and download, guaranteed and dedicated to the streaming service.
Wi-Fi connections cannot be used.
To this network will be connected a router from which all the streaming equipment will be connected to.
The IP that will be assigned to the router must be able to make outgoing connections to the following ports / ip:
- TCP ports from 1195 to 1199 to IP 213.137.32.108
- UDP ports from 10001 to 10004 towards IP 213.137.32.108
- UDP ports from 10001 to 10004 towards IP 178.20.73.121
We are again planning on using the ports (marked by blue painters tape) on the recessed east wall of the Grand Hall mezzanine.
TNS, I wanted to check with you the following:
1. Are all these port settings still in place and if not could they please be restored?
2. Would it be possible for Daniel when he is at Powerhouse this coming Wednesday (Feb. 7) to connect with Deesh and go up to the mezzanine and do a streaming test?
3. Erika, I am very sorry this ask comes in again so late, but we are also hoping to be able to have a TNS technician onsite 8am-11am on February 11.
Let us know if this is all doable.
Thank you so much.
Pamela
--

So when I spoke with Dan I explained this and asked if he would consult with her a little to understand her needs in the bigger picture -- maybe she'd do better with a Windows machine? or one of each? -- so we can consider how to get her set up best, and make sure she knows we're here to help.

Hello,
Looping in +David Koosis here as well, since we've already started getting this ball rolling. Since last week my computer has been strange:
1. My Slack isn't very responsive on my computer. Nothing new really comes in or if it comes in, it is severely delayed. The notifications for my new Slack messages don't disappear after reading the message.
* At this point, I am mostly using Slack on my phone
* I am able to send messages, I just can't see any responses on my computer
1. I keep getting the below prompt from Slack to install a new helper tool but it never goes away—even if I type my password in OR if I hit cancel:
*
1. Last week, my Excel basically stopped working. No matter what the spreadsheet is (if I had previously been able to edit that spreadsheet or not). I would get the below message:
*
1. Finally, I restarted my computer to see if that would resolve the issue. When it came back online, I had to re-sign in to everything (which was kinda expected) BUT also, my Zoom was logged out, and the dock was reset. I had to select "Keep in Dock" for all of the apps that had previously already been there. This is less of a problem but mostly just strange.
Anyway, my computer is mostly usable right now, tomorrow is a good day to touchbase and troubleshoot.
Thank you,
Jen

1. At this point, I am mostly using Slack on my phone
2. I am able to send messages, I just can't see any responses on my
computer
2. I keep getting the below prompt from Slack to install a new helper
tool but it never goes away—even if I type my password in OR if I hit
cancel:
1. [image: Screenshot 2024-04-16 at 3.33.52 PM.png]
3. Last week, my Excel basically stopped working. No matter what the
spreadsheet is (if I had previously been able to edit that spreadsheet or
not). I would get the below message:
1. [image: Screenshot 2024-04-11 at 2.42.30 PM.png]
4. Finally, I restarted my computer to see if that would resolve the
issue. When it came back online, I had to re-sign in to everything (which
was kinda expected) BUT also, my Zoom was logged out, and the dock was
reset. I had to select "Keep in Dock" for all of the apps that had
previously already been there. This is less of a problem but mostly just
strange.
Anyway, my computer is mostly usable right now, tomorrow is a good day to
touchbase and troubleshoot.
Thank you,
Jen

From: ARTERNAL >
Date: Tue, Sep 10, 2024 at 10:02 AM
Subject: Your inbox is disconnected from Arternal
To: >
Hello,
Your email inbox megan@powerhousearts.org has been disconnected from your Arternal account.
This connection is important because it allows you to send email from Arternal, automatically track and log emails from your inbox. The most common reason this happens is a password or permissions change.
Reconnecting your inbox will only take a moment. You can do so from the Settings -> Email Settings in the left hand side bar.
See this article for more detailed instructions on how to connect your inbox.
--

=== EMAIL START ===
From: David Koosis <vcto@powerhousearts.org>
To: "The TNS Group, Support Team" <support@thetnsgroup.com>
Date: 2023-11-29 19:49:53
Subject: WiFi requirements for events

Goal: Make WiFi access easy and performant for Powerhouse clients who rent
the space for events, and for event attendees.
These are considerations:
1/ Event techs (Powerhouse clients) need sustained access throughout the
entire event. 30-minute timed connections (which I'm told are current guest
network settings) don't work well.
2/ Event techs may need to stream a movie, Zoom call, or do some other
high bandwidth activity while presenting to event attendees.
3/ The event might include live auction-by-app. These apps are bursty,
with potentially hundreds of phones hitting the carrier or WiFi
simultaneously. Do you have relevant client experience?
Can you please:
1/ Characterize the current network performance as it relates to above.
2/ Propose options for an ideal Event tech experience
3/ Propose options for an ideal (passwordless?) event attendees experience
This is strategic not time urgent.
Thank you
/dk
Goal: Make WiFi access easy and performant for Powerhouse clients who rent the space for events, and for event attendees. These are considerations: 1/ Event techs (Powerhouse clients) need sustained access throughout the entire event. 30-minute timed connections (which I'm told are current guest network settings) don't work well. 2/ Event techs may need to stream a movie, Zoom call, or do some other high bandwidth activity while presenting to event attendees. 3/ The event might include live auction-by-app. These apps are bursty, with potentially hundreds of phones hitting the carrier or WiFi simultaneously. Do you have relevant client experience? Can you please: 1/ Characterize the current network performance as it relates to above. 2/ Propose options for an ideal Event tech experience 3/ Propose options for an ideal (passwordless?) event attendees experience This is strategic not time urgent. Thank you /dk

=== EMAIL START ===
From: David Koosis <vcto@powerhousearts.org>
To: Mitch Roth <mitch@powerhousearts.org>
Date: 2024-03-28 16:00:59
Subject: Re: CCTV Down

Mitch
Let's figure out a way to shortcut the communication on these. Got ideas?
We have a typical kind of pattern:
There's an issue with some system. We reach out to the vendor responsible
for the camera, or the schlage locks and readers, or the building alerts,
or the video storage servers.
That vendor tells you it may have to do with the network or POE.
You tell me.
I tell TNS usually.
And we end up going back and forth without confidence that knowledgeable
people are communicating and fixing.
If it's something hot we could call an incident protocol and get both
parties on a call.
I'll also see if we can come up with easy ways for everyone to know the POE
status of every port, so the question won't need to be asked.
Let's talk it thru and figure out something.
Thanks!
Mitch Let's figure out a way to shortcut the communication on these. Got ideas? We have a typical kind of pattern: There's an issue with some system. We reach out to the vendor responsible for the camera, or the schlage locks and readers, or the building alerts, or the video storage servers. That vendor tells you it may have to do with the network or POE. You tell me. I tell TNS usually. And we end up going back and forth without confidence that knowledgeable people are communicating and fixing. If it's something hot we could call an incident protocol and get both parties on a call. I'll also see if we can come up with easy ways for everyone to know the POE status of every port, so the question won't need to be asked. Let's talk it thru and figure out something. Thanks! === EMAIL START ===
From: David Koosis <vcto@powerhousearts.org>
To: Phoenix <phoenix@powerhousearts.org>, Daniel Lucas <DLucas@thetnsgroup.com>, 
	Robert Nieves <rnieves@thetnsgroup.com>
Date: 2023-11-29 15:57:23
Subject: Gatehouse WiFi  #decision

Hello folks, and thank you for a productive meeting earlier today. Please
correct, confirm, or add to this to make it better:
*goal: *provide WiFi in the gatehouse so that the new security vendor can
access their WiFi camera for the purpose of monitoring security staff.
*#decision*: re-allocate a Meraki wireless access point from the 2nd floor
area leased to Workspace11 over to the switch cabinet at the gatehouse.
Notes:
- Workspace11 does not use Powerhouse WiFi, so the WiFi access points
will not be missed.
- Powerhouse doesn't depend on the Workspace11 WiFi access points for
any building management devices.
- @Daniel Lucas will remove an AP from
Workspace11
- @Daniel Lucas will install and configure the
AP at the gatehouse
- We considered asking the vendor to put a hardwired camera instead of
WiFi: this would let us plug directly into an existing switch which @Robert
Nieves informed us exists in the gatehouse
cabinet. This would have the advantage of not requiring an AP. We rejected
this because Phoenix knows the vendor standardized on the approach and the
brand they installed, so it's not worth introducing something different.
- There are three dual-port RJ45 plates in the gatehouse. Two of them
are live, connected to two patch cables running back to the main building
IT closet
- @Daniel Lucas before end of year, will test
and label the ports in the gatehouse. There's a cable tester and labeler
sitting on the desk that David usually sits at.
- @Phoenix will follow up with Genetec
vendor to ask "When were the Genetec PC's last patched and who is
responsible to do that?" (It would also be worth asking about the
Genetec-connected camera firmware.)

Thanks! On Wed, Aug 7, 2024 at 1:38 PM Ellie Hayworth wrote: Hi All, I did a bit of poking around and zkipster recommends that we whitelabel our emails. I believe we had attempted to do this a few weeks back, am I correct @Megan Skidmore ? It would be wonderful if we can have someone who is an administrator on the account look at the Account Settings to confirm that this has been done, as it is a best practice zkipster recommends. Article on White Labeling below: https://support.zkipster.com/en/articles/2687348-how-to-whitelabel-domains-and-email-addresses-in-zkipster Beyond that, I think we need to trust zkipster to do what it does best. I'm wary of removing too much of the brand identity in the form of images for this distribution because we want folks to be enticed to buy tickets. Further, I'm not sure how to embed images via HTML vs simply uploading using the platform's image uploader tool. The email marketing component of the program is a big selling point so I imagine they've taken care to mitigate these potential pitfalls but I'm of course mindful if anyone feels differently... There is also an interesting note at the bottom of this article on zkipsters FAQs pages that describes the issue @Sam Polcer may have been facing, e.g. the anti-spoof filter caught the email because it was indeed an outside email domain (we are not white labeled and it is showing up from an intermediary) "masquerading" as Powerhouse Arts. See article here: https://support.zkipster.com/en/articles/8467062-faqs-on-invitations All this is to say, I think we can't avoid the simple fact that some filters will catch these as spam, but if we whitelabel we should be in a better place. @Megan Skidmore - as far as distribution, I too am eager to get these out. I'll get a few more tests out to the internal comms team today with the final round edits and await the go-ahead. If we indeed need to wait for the tax deductible information, I'm happy to do so, but I am also feeling as though we need to get this out in the next few days (at the latest first thing next week) in order to best position us for success. Thanks, Ellie On Wed, Aug 7, 2024 at 1:13 PM Megan Skidmore wrote: Hi David and Ellie, David - this is going out through Zkipster, not Mailchimp. Thanks, Megan On Tue, Aug 6, 2024 at 9:16 PM David Koosis wrote: I verified that it gets mediocre marks from spam filters, including Google's. Depending on how stringent the recipient is setup, this will result in some single digit percent getting sent to spam, I'd estimate. I think breaking up the big image is important. When I realized the HTML text was there, I took a closer look and see that there's a little bit of funkiness that could be tightened. Much more relevant is the outgoing big batch send. If we're doing that through MailChimp, then you already have experience with the list and know what to expect. If it's going out through zkipster, we should definitely do some cleaning up. Your point is interesting: did you get a message that explained it as you describe? We have local email rules that will flag messages that claim to be from someone in the Powerhouse directory but originate from a non-powerhouse address ("Eric Shiner" ). On Tue, Aug 6, 2024, 8:22 PM Sam Polcer wrote: All- note that this conversation was started when I received a test version that was flagged, but to be specific it was flagged for me because it had the word Powerhouse Arts in the sender name, and that’s a part of mine. Have we verified that non-PHA folks are getting a flag upon receipt, too? Let’s test it before we spend too much time effort mitigating! Apologies for mentioning this so late. -Sam (sent from my phone) On Aug 6, 2024, at 8:00 PM, David Koosis wrote: ﻿ I take it back about the one big image. What I saw was an artifact of my email reader; I see that your email has a big image followed by text, including the unsubscribe link as plain text. I think the rest of what I recommended stands, but I'd like to see it as you send it (rather than as I received it). LMK. Thanks /dk On Tue, Aug 6, 2024 at 7:10 PM David Koosis wrote: Maggie, Ellie, Sam: I'm excited that you guys are making this event happen! Kudos. Here are some recommendations, more or less in priority order, which will make a big difference in email deliverability. After the recommendations I include some details on my findings, just for reference. Let me know if I can help with any of this, and I'll be happy to. Recommendations Don't send the email as one big image. That's a major red flag for spam algorithms. Instead, convert it to HTML. We should be able to retain the images and great design. Include a text version of the message. When you send an email, you can include both a plaintext and an html-formatted version; in almost every case, the plaintext version is ignored and the HTML is displayed, but for our purposes it's a key factor. Include a "preheader," which is text you can put in the HTML version of the email to get displayed as a "preview" in the email reader. If you can make the aesthetics work, put a text footer including contact info and an unsubscribe link. If we have access to the recipient's name, try and make it work as part of the subject line, content, or preheader text. "Thanks for your pledge, Ellie! We'll see you at dinner!" These acknowledgements are going out one-by-one, but even more of a risk for spam issues is the 3,000 invitations you plan to send out . Can you tell me more about that, and how you plan to send it? Don't send it before we speak, ok? Findings A Significant Number of Incoming Test Emails Got Flagged as Suspicious I see seven incoming emails to powerhousearts.org from worldsbest.events in the past seven days. Two or three of them got tagged as suspicious by Google. I can't see exactly why they were flagged (you know: it's a machine learning algorithm), but I have some ideas. Email Hygiene Looks Good There are a few kinds of system-level issues that can get your email flagged as spam. On that front, the email looks good. Specifically: The email complies with DKIM, DMARC, SPF , which are anti-fraud protocols that Google and Yahoo have recently been enforcing more stringently. The email uses TLS , which is a preferred encryption method. The domain passes FCrDNS , which protects against spammers impersonating a domain. The email does NOT use Mail Transfer Agent Strict Transport Security ( MTA-STS ), which is a for encrypting messages sent between two mail servers, but I don't think that's a relevant shortcoming for us. We don't support BIMI , but that's a nice-to-have, not a security issue. (I recommend we should do it for marketing reasons, Sam.) That's all positive and above-average. Again, I think it's an exciting and important thing you're doing for PHA; really! Let me know however I can. Cheers /dk On Tue, Aug 6, 2024 at 5:29 PM David Koosis wrote: Hi Ellie I'm so sorry for the delay in responding. TBH, I just didn't spot it as a priority among the thousand emails in my inbox. The work you're doing is very important to the organization; please help me out by calling or texting me directly at 646-481-4141 if I don't respond timely. And I'll tweak my email filters as well. 🙏🏻 With regard to spam... Yes, that's concerning. I'll run traces and take a closer look at what's going on now. Where does worldsbest.events come from? /dk On Mon, Aug 5, 2024 at 11:00 AM Ellie Hayworth wrote: Hi David, I’m just following up here, as it would be wonderful to receive your insight as to how best to mitigate hitting spam filters during this save the date distribution. Thank you, Ellie h a y w o r t h Ellie Hayworth , Founder communications | public relations | digital marketing | storytelling W E B : hayworth.co I G : @ellie.hayworth | @hayworth.co CONFIDENTIALITY NOTICE : The contents of this email message and any attachments are intended solely for the addressee(s) and may contain confidential and/or privileged information and may be legally protected from disclosure. On Wed, Jul 31, 2024 at 1:25 PM Ellie Hayworth wrote: Hi David, I trust this note finds you well. I am forwarding the latest version of the Save the Date, below. === EMAIL START ===
From: Ellie Hayworth <ellie@hayworth.co>
To: Megan Skidmore <megan@powerhousearts.org>
Date: 2024-08-07 13:37:45
Subject: Re: Save the Date | Artists Celebration Dinner | October 7

Hi All,
I did a bit of poking around and zkipster recommends that we whitelabel our
emails. I believe we had attempted to do this a few weeks back, am I
correct @Megan Skidmore ? It would be wonderful
if we can have someone who is an administrator on the account look at the
Account Settings to confirm that this has been done, as it is a best
practice zkipster recommends.
Article on White Labeling below:
https://support.zkipster.com/en/articles/2687348-how-to-whitelabel-domains-and-email-addresses-in-zkipster
Beyond that, I think we need to trust zkipster to do what it does best. I'm
wary of removing too much of the brand identity in the form of images for
this distribution because we want folks to be enticed to buy tickets.
Further, I'm not sure how to embed images via HTML vs simply uploading
using the platform's image uploader tool. The email marketing component of
the program is a big selling point so I imagine they've taken care to
mitigate these potential pitfalls but I'm of course mindful if anyone feels
differently...
There is also an interesting note at the bottom of this article on
zkipsters FAQs pages that describes the issue @Sam Polcer
may have been facing, e.g. the anti-spoof filter
caught the email because it was indeed an outside email domain (we are not
white labeled and it is showing up from an intermediary) "masquerading" as
Powerhouse Arts.
See article here:
https://support.zkipster.com/en/articles/8467062-faqs-on-invitations
All this is to say, I think we can't avoid the simple fact that some
filters will catch these as spam, but if we whitelabel we should be in a
better place.
@Megan Skidmore - as far as distribution, I too
am eager to get these out. I'll get a few more tests out to the internal
comms team today with the final round edits and await the go-ahead. If we
indeed need to wait for the tax deductible information, I'm happy to do so,
but I am also feeling as though we need to get this out in the next few
days (at the latest first thing next week) in order to best position us for
success.
Thanks,
Ellie

Hi David and Ellie, David - this is going out through Zkipster, not Mailchimp. Catching up on this chain. @Ellie Hayworth - what are your thoughts on David's recommendations for improved layout and list sending? And can you stagger batch sending? I don't think we can get around the singular large image - looping @Jeff Quinn in here for his awareness of all, especially with consideration to the Invite design forthcoming. Eager to move this forward and ideally get it out by tomorrow. Ellie, still awaiting Eric's response on sending with the dinner levels sans tax-deductible portion, as we're still awaiting the final rentals cost to factor in. Thanks, Megan On Tue, Aug 6, 2024 at 9:16 PM David Koosis wrote: I verified that it gets mediocre marks from spam filters, including Google's. Depending on how stringent the recipient is setup, this will result in some single digit percent getting sent to spam, I'd estimate. I think breaking up the big image is important. When I realized the HTML text was there, I took a closer look and see that there's a little bit of funkiness that could be tightened. Much more relevant is the outgoing big batch send. If we're doing that through MailChimp, then you already have experience with the list and know what to expect. If it's going out through zkipster, we should definitely do some cleaning up. Your point is interesting: did you get a message that explained it as you describe? We have local email rules that will flag messages that claim to be from someone in the Powerhouse directory but originate from a non-powerhouse address ("Eric Shiner" ). On Tue, Aug 6, 2024, 8:22 PM Sam Polcer wrote: All- note that this conversation was started when I received a test version that was flagged, but to be specific it was flagged for me because it had the word Powerhouse Arts in the sender name, and that’s a part of mine. Have we verified that non-PHA folks are getting a flag upon receipt, too? Let’s test it before we spend too much time effort mitigating! Apologies for mentioning this so late. -Sam (sent from my phone) On Aug 6, 2024, at 8:00 PM, David Koosis wrote: ﻿ I take it back about the one big image. What I saw was an artifact of my email reader; I see that your email has a big image followed by text, including the unsubscribe link as plain text. I think the rest of what I recommended stands, but I'd like to see it as you send it (rather than as I received it). LMK. Thanks /dk On Tue, Aug 6, 2024 at 7:10 PM David Koosis wrote: Maggie, Ellie, Sam: I'm excited that you guys are making this event happen! Kudos. Here are some recommendations, more or less in priority order, which will make a big difference in email deliverability. After the recommendations I include some details on my findings, just for reference. Let me know if I can help with any of this, and I'll be happy to. Recommendations Don't send the email as one big image. That's a major red flag for spam algorithms. Instead, convert it to HTML. We should be able to retain the images and great design. Include a text version of the message. When you send an email, you can include both a plaintext and an html-formatted version; in almost every case, the plaintext version is ignored and the HTML is displayed, but for our purposes it's a key factor. Include a "preheader," which is text you can put in the HTML version of the email to get displayed as a "preview" in the email reader. If you can make the aesthetics work, put a text footer including contact info and an unsubscribe link. If we have access to the recipient's name, try and make it work as part of the subject line, content, or preheader text. "Thanks for your pledge, Ellie! We'll see you at dinner!" These acknowledgements are going out one-by-one, but even more of a risk for spam issues is the 3,000 invitations you plan to send out . Can you tell me more about that, and how you plan to send it? Don't send it before we speak, ok? Findings A Significant Number of Incoming Test Emails Got Flagged as Suspicious I see seven incoming emails to powerhousearts.org from worldsbest.events in the past seven days. Two or three of them got tagged as suspicious by Google. I can't see exactly why they were flagged (you know: it's a machine learning algorithm), but I have some ideas. Email Hygiene Looks Good There are a few kinds of system-level issues that can get your email flagged as spam. On that front, the email looks good. Specifically: The email complies with DKIM, DMARC, SPF , which are anti-fraud protocols that Google and Yahoo have recently been enforcing more stringently. The email uses TLS , which is a preferred encryption method. The domain passes FCrDNS , which protects against spammers impersonating a domain. The email does NOT use Mail Transfer Agent Strict Transport Security ( MTA-STS ), which is a for encrypting messages sent between two mail servers, but I don't think that's a relevant shortcoming for us. We don't support BIMI , but that's a nice-to-have, not a security issue. (I recommend we should do it for marketing reasons, Sam.) That's all positive and above-average. Again, I think it's an exciting and important thing you're doing for PHA; really! Let me know however I can. Cheers /dk On Tue, Aug 6, 2024 at 5:29 PM David Koosis wrote: Hi Ellie I'm so sorry for the delay in responding. TBH, I just didn't spot it as a priority among the thousand emails in my inbox. The work you're doing is very important to the organization; please help me out by calling or texting me directly at 646-481-4141 if I don't respond timely. And I'll tweak my email filters as well. 🙏🏻 With regard to spam... Yes, that's concerning. I'll run traces and take a closer look at what's going on now. Where does worldsbest.events come from? /dk On Mon, Aug 5, 2024 at 11:00 AM Ellie Hayworth wrote: Hi David, I’m just following up here, as it would be wonderful to receive your insight as to how best to mitigate hitting spam filters during this save the date distribution. I verified that it gets mediocre marks from spam filters, including
Google's. Depending on how stringent the recipient is setup, this will
result in some single digit percent getting sent to spam, I'd estimate.

funkiness that could be tightened.

=== EMAIL START ===
From: David Koosis <vcto@powerhousearts.org>
To: Ellie Hayworth <ellie@hayworth.co>
Date: 2024-08-06 19:10:26
Subject: Re: Save the Date | Artists Celebration Dinner | October 7

Maggie, Ellie, Sam:
I'm excited that you guys are making this event happen! Kudos.
Here are some recommendations, more or less in priority order, which will
make a big difference in email deliverability.
After the recommendations I include some details on my findings, just for
reference.
Let me know if I can help with any of this, and I'll be happy to.
*Recommendations*
- Don't send the email as one big image. That's a major red flag for
spam algorithms. Instead, convert it to HTML. We should be able to retain
the images and great design.
- Include a text version of the message. When you send an email, you can
include both a plaintext and an html-formatted version; in almost every
case, the plaintext version is ignored and the HTML is displayed, but for
our purposes it's a key factor.
- Include a "preheader," which is text you can put in the HTML version
of the email to get displayed as a "preview" in the email reader.
- If you can make the aesthetics work, put a text footer including
contact info and an unsubscribe link.
- If we have access to the recipient's name, try and make it work as
part of the subject line, content, or preheader text. "Thanks for your
pledge, Ellie! We'll see you at dinner!"
- These acknowledgements are going out one-by-one, but *even more of a
risk for spam issues is the 3,000 invitations you plan to send out*. Can
you tell me more about that, and how you plan to send it? Don't send it
before we speak, ok?
*Findings*
*A Significant Number of Incoming Test Emails Got Flagged as Suspicious*
I see seven incoming emails to powerhousearts.org from worldsbest.events in
the past seven days. Two or three of them got tagged as suspicious by
Google. I can't see exactly why they were flagged (you know: it's a machine
learning algorithm), but I have some ideas.
*Email Hygiene Looks Good*
There are a few kinds of system-level issues that can get your email
flagged as spam. On that front, the email looks good. Specifically:
- The email complies with DKIM, DMARC, SPF
,
which are anti-fraud protocols that Google and Yahoo have recently
been enforcing more stringently.
- The email uses TLS
,
which is a preferred encryption method.
- The domain passes FCrDNS ,
which protects against spammers impersonating a domain.
- The email does NOT use Mail Transfer Agent Strict Transport Security (
MTA-STS
),
which is a for encrypting messages sent between two mail servers, but I
don't think that's a relevant shortcoming for us.
- We don't support BIMI
, but that's a
nice-to-have, not a security issue. (I recommend we should do it for
marketing reasons, Sam.)
That's all positive and above-average.
Again, I think it's an exciting and important thing you're doing for PHA;
really! Let me know however I can.
Cheers
/dk
=== EMAIL END ===

From: Mitch Roth >
Date: Thu, Oct 19, 2023 at 9:22 AM
Subject: Online Generator Test / November 21 @ 5:15p
To: Erica Ellis >
Cc: Steven Battaglia >, Erdinc Kaynas >, Phoenix Lindsey-Hall >, Julia Margaret Lu >
Hi Erica,
On Tuesday November 21 @ 5:15p along with my vendor I will be conducting an online generator test. This is when we turn off the electricity to the building and the electricity is restored to the building from the generator. As you know when the electricity is restored this can sometimes cause problems to sensitive equipment such as the servers due to the surge. I will be sending an email out to the Powerhouse Arts staff soon to tell them to turn off their computers 15 minutes prior to the start of the online generator test, shall I have them unplug them too ? Additionally, I think I should have a TNS tech on site during this time to check the UPS and in case something goes wrong as I plan to reopen the building at 7:00p since we are open during the week until 10:00p.
Any recommendations for this online generator test and how we shall proceed ?
Thank you in advance,
Mitch

Hi TNS Group (Omega?) Is there an Omega email we should be addressing?
Can you add a second phone to the 4th floor print shop (same number as the
existing print shop phone) on the West side of the floor with the volume
set to the highest setting so Luther can hear it over the machines?

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Julia Margaret Lu
Date: Thu, Aug 1, 2024 at 3:52 PM
Subject: Re: Vehicle Access at PHA: Visitors, Gatehouse, Parking
To: Luther Davis
Cc: Mitch Roth
Hi Luther, thanks for sharing your concerns while on vacation, and I'm
sorry you can't hear the phone across the room.
1, we should add a second phone to the other end of the print shop so you
can be alerted when visitors and deliveries have arrived. I'll push this to
IT/Omega (fka TNS)
2, you can cc group_security when scheduling visits
3, you can also *call* the security desk to let them know you are expecting
a visitor so that they are not turned away
We don't want to make this more difficult for you! Flagging things like the
phone being too far away are easily solved, and we should build
tools/systems that make everything easier for your workflow.
Julia

Flagging things like the phone being too far away are easily solved, and we should build tools/systems that make everything easier for your workflow. Julia On Thu, Aug 1, 2024 at 3:40 PM Luther Davis wrote: What happens when they go up 2nd St? I have concerns because… 1. This now requires an extra 600 to 700 emails a year for the printshop 2. A telephone call means someone needs to stop fabricating, wash their hands or take off their PPE to answer a phone and they have to do it in the incredibly short amount of time that our phone system rings. Before I left Mitch tried to call the printshop repeatedly but we couldn’t hear him over the machines. He never reached me or the printshop staff and our delivery agent had to call tour customer and they had to send and email to reach us. I appreciate you trying to get the gate house to do their job. However I feel this approach is flawed and now has me running the full length of the build to reach a phone that I can barely hear and that I will always have to have my cellphone on me or stand by it while it’s being charged. If this is going to work I will need a permanent fix to the flawed our phone system. Yes I am on vacation and that’s how much I care about this issue. L On Thu, Aug 1, 2024 at 8:46 PM Julia Margaret Lu wrote: Good Afternoon Colleagues, Over the past few weeks there have been some conflicts with visitors at the gatehouse on why they are being detained when this didn't happen before. In the past the gatehouse security guards were not doing their jobs and they were just letting everybody through. Mitch and I have been cracking down on security to keep everyone and our facility safe. To reduce the conflicts at the gatehouse for visitors please see the security protocols for guests, vendors, and special deliveries: There are 2 ways for vehicular guests to gain access to Powerhouse Arts: 1. Email the security team in advance at group_security@powerhousearts.org and state the following : Name of the person Date and time expected Include parking accommodations (Garage or Forecourt) The security team will see this email and grant access to the visitor when they arrive. 2. Unannounced/unexpected visitors: If a guest shows up at the gatehouse the security protocol is to ask them for a contact person. The security team has a staff list with phone numbers for Powerhouse Arts, Workspace 11, Alpha Workshops, and Manhattan Graphics Center. The gatehouse security guard will call that person to verify if they should be granted access to the Powerhouse Arts building. Please share this protocol with your guests, vendors and for deliveries. Additionally, please provide a backup contact if you potentially might not be available and be mindful that if you do not answer your phone from the security team there could be a delay. If the security team isn't able to connect with the contact person then they will then be required to contact the engineering department so they can then find the contact person. As a reminder, visitors and visiting artists may request parking, but Ceramics members are limited to Forecourt parking only when loading and unloading. THANK YOU for your continued cooperation and dedication to keeping Powerhouse safe :) Please email Mitch and I directly if you have any questions/concerns. - Julia + Mitch -- Julia Margaret Lu (she/her) Operations Manager Powerhouse Arts Find a time to meet with Julia julia@powerhousearts.org cell (917) 304 9528 322 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11215 www.powerhousearts.org

I hope you're getting some relief from the back issue. /dk Wireless Access Point – MR Enterprise: Renewal cost for support is $283/device, multiplied by a quantity of 70 devices = $19,810. Powerhouse will need to review your current subscriptions for support by 6/21/2025. From there, Powerhouse will not pay for these subscriptions until the renewal is up in 3 years. === On Tue, Apr 9, 2024 at 5:03 PM Erika Ellis wrote:
Hi David,
See below. I am more than happy to discuss through this tomorrow during our meeting. Many thanks, Erika
Estimated Cost:
Estimated cost for each unit/device All renewals for support (subscriptions) are subject to change per the vendor – TNS does not have any control over that We pull the data that is available from the vendor and if it is not available, we look at past trends to estimate the cost
Estimated Extended Cost:
The cost Estimated is the total of Estimated Cost x quantity Cost multiplied by quantity to provide the full cost for the renewal, per term.
Term Estimated
A vendor can change the term of a renewal term at any time, for example, if a 3-year term was offered in the past, they may have a reason to pull it
and only provide a 1-year term – TNS does not have control over this (it is usually a specific situation that this would change)
1-year or 3-year
This is the life of the renewal. The equipment subscription is in place for 1 year or 3 years pending term. If it is a 3-year term, you will not renew
the subscriptions/renewals until 3 years later.
Expiration Date
That is when your current renewal/subscription expires. TNS sends out quotes 30-60 days in advance of the expiration date to maintain support on the
devices. Also, if Meraki support is not renewed, Meraki will shut down the devices, so they are no longer live in your environment.
For example:
Wireless Access Point – MR Enterprise: Renewal cost for support is $283/device, multiplied by a quantity of 70 devices = $19,810. Powerhouse will need to review your current subscriptions for support by
6/21/2025.
From there, Powerhouse will not pay for these subscriptions until the renewal is up in 3 years.

On Fri, Apr 5, 2024 at 8:45 AM Erika Ellis
wrote:
Hi Steven,
Cost Projections as requested:
Additional Users:
Powerhouse contracts supports 60 users.
For 5 additional users to 15 users, the pricing will be $125/user/month with a few caveats:
The $125/user/month is based on the current environment. When we spec out our Total Care services (Managed Services) we consider and incorporate all the hardware that we manage and users as well.
If your equipment remains the same, and you are not adding another 10 switches (as example) we are safe with the $125/user per month
Unless any processes change, I will not uplift or increase the contract for 5 users, it would start at 10 additional.
Security Components:
Managed Detection Response (EDR) with AMTD (Automated Moving Target Defense - see attached
This solution is based on the number of devices – I used 94 devices based on what is in your environment now. If devices go up or down, the pricing will change.
EDR AMTD
94 X $11.50 = $1,081.00 (monthly pricing)
One-Time Setup $999
CAT+ (Phish Testing and Security Awareness Training)
This is based on users – I used 75 below
75 X $3.25 = $243.75 (Monthly pricing)
Setup $999 (One-time setup)
Lastly, Dan sent over the warranty report for systems to David. I put in a request for the renewal budget and should have that no later than mid-week
next week, if not sooner.
Please let me know if you have any questions or need anything further.
Have a great weekend and I look forward to seeing you next Wednesday! Erika

From: Erika Ellis <eellis@omegasystemscorp.com>
To: David Koosis <vcto@powerhousearts.org>
Date: 2024-04-09 21:02:37
Subject: RE: Headcount growth

Hi David,
See below. I am more than happy to discuss through this tomorrow during our meeting. Many thanks, Erika
Estimated Cost:
* Estimated cost for each unit/device
* All renewals for support (subscriptions) are subject to change per the vendor – TNS does not have any control over that
* We pull the data that is available from the vendor and if it is not available, we look at past trends to estimate the cost
Estimated Extended Cost:
* The cost Estimated is the total of Estimated Cost x quantity Cost multiplied by quantity to provide the full cost for the renewal, per term.
Term Estimated
* A vendor can change the term of a renewal term at any time, for example, if a 3-year term was offered in the past, they may have a reason to pull it and only provide a 1-year term – TNS does not have control over this (it is usually a specific situation that this would change)
1-year or 3-year
* This is the life of the renewal. The equipment subscription is in place for 1 year or 3 years pending term. If it is a 3-year term, you will not renew the subscriptions/renewals until 3 years later.
Expiration Date
* That is when your current renewal/subscription expires. TNS sends out quotes 30-60 days in advance of the expiration date to maintain support on the devices. Also, if Meraki support is not renewed, Meraki will shut down the devices, so they are no longer live in your environment.
For example:
Wireless Access Point – MR Enterprise: Renewal cost for support is $283/device, multiplied by a quantity of 70 devices = $19,810. Powerhouse will need to review your current subscriptions for support by 6/21/2025.
Erika Ellis | Technical Account Manager
Office 203-316-0112 | Direct 203-316-0112
Mobile 203-981-8902 | Email eellis@omegasystemscorp.com

Hi Steven,
Cost Projections as requested:
Additional Users:
* Powerhouse contracts supports 60 users.
* For 5 additional users to 15 users, the pricing will be $125/user/month with a few caveats:
* The $125/user/month is based on the current environment. When we spec out our Total Care services (Managed Services) we consider and incorporate all the hardware that we manage and users as well.
* If your equipment remains the same, and you are not adding another 10 switches (as example) we are safe with the $125/user per month
* Unless any processes change, I will not uplift or increase the contract for 5 users, it would start at 10 additional.
Security Components:
1. Managed Detection Response (EDR) with AMTD (Automated Moving Target Defense - see attached
* This solution is based on the number of devices – I used 94 devices based on what is in your environment now. If devices go up or down, the pricing will change.
EDR AMTD
94 X $11.50 = $1,081.00 (monthly pricing)
One-Time Setup $999
1. CAT+ (Phish Testing and Security Awareness Training)
* This is based on users – I used 75 below
75 X $3.25 = $243.75 (Monthly pricing)
Setup $999 (One-time setup)
Lastly, Dan sent over the warranty report for systems to David. I put in a request for the renewal budget and should have that no later than mid-week next week, if not sooner.
Please let me know if you have any questions or need anything further.
Have a great weekend and I look forward to seeing you next Wednesday! Erika

Hi David,
See below. I am more than happy to discuss through this tomorrow during our meeting. Many thanks, Erika
Estimated Cost:
Estimated cost for each unit/device All renewals for support (subscriptions) are subject to change per the vendor – TNS does not have any control over that We pull the data that is available from the vendor and if it is not available, we look at past trends to estimate the cost
Estimated Extended Cost:
The cost Estimated is the total of Estimated Cost x quantity Cost multiplied by quantity to provide the full cost for the renewal, per term.
Term Estimated
A vendor can change the term of a renewal term at any time, for example, if a 3-year term was offered in the past, they may have a reason to pull it
and only provide a 1-year term – TNS does not have control over this (it is usually a specific situation that this would change)
1-year or 3-year
This is the life of the renewal. The equipment subscription is in place for 1 year or 3 years pending term. If it is a 3-year term, you will not renew
the subscriptions/renewals until 3 years later.
Expiration Date
That is when your current renewal/subscription expires. TNS sends out quotes 30-60 days in advance of the expiration date to maintain support on the
devices. Also, if Meraki support is not renewed, Meraki will shut down the devices, so they are no longer live in your environment.
For example:
Wireless Access Point – MR Enterprise: Renewal cost for support is $283/device, multiplied by a quantity of 70 devices = $19,810. Powerhouse will need to review your current subscriptions for support by
6/21/2025.
From there, Powerhouse will not pay for these subscriptions until the renewal is up in 3 years.

On Fri, Apr 5, 2024 at 8:45 AM Erika Ellis
wrote:
Hi Steven,
Cost Projections as requested:
Additional Users:
Powerhouse contracts supports 60 users.
For 5 additional users to 15 users, the pricing will be $125/user/month with a few caveats:
The $125/user/month is based on the current environment. When we spec out our Total Care services (Managed Services) we consider and incorporate all the hardware that we manage and users as well.
If your equipment remains the same, and you are not adding another 10 switches (as example) we are safe with the $125/user per month
Unless any processes change, I will not uplift or increase the contract for 5 users, it would start at 10 additional.
Security Components:
Managed Detection Response (EDR) with AMTD (Automated Moving Target Defense - see attached
This solution is based on the number of devices – I used 94 devices based on what is in your environment now. If devices go up or down, the pricing will change.
EDR AMTD
94 X $11.50 = $1,081.00 (monthly pricing)
One-Time Setup $999
CAT+ (Phish Testing and Security Awareness Training)
This is based on users – I used 75 below
75 X $3.25 = $243.75 (Monthly pricing)
Setup $999 (One-time setup)
Lastly, Dan sent over the warranty report for systems to David. I put in a request for the renewal budget and should have that no later than mid-week
next week, if not sooner.
Please let me know if you have any questions or need anything further.
Have a great weekend and I look forward to seeing you next Wednesday! Erika

Hi Steven,
Cost Projections as requested:
Additional Users:
* Powerhouse contracts supports 60 users.
* For 5 additional users to 15 users, the pricing will be $125/user/month with a few caveats:
* The $125/user/month is based on the current environment. When we spec out our Total Care services (Managed Services) we consider and incorporate all the hardware that we manage and users as well.
* If your equipment remains the same, and you are not adding another 10 switches (as example) we are safe with the $125/user per month
* Unless any processes change, I will not uplift or increase the contract for 5 users, it would start at 10 additional.
Security Components:
1. Managed Detection Response (EDR) with AMTD (Automated Moving Target Defense - see attached
* This solution is based on the number of devices – I used 94 devices based on what is in your environment now. If devices go up or down, the pricing will change.
EDR AMTD
94 X $11.50 = $1,081.00 (monthly pricing)
One-Time Setup $999
1. CAT+ (Phish Testing and Security Awareness Training)
* This is based on users – I used 75 below
75 X $3.25 = $243.75 (Monthly pricing)
Setup $999 (One-time setup)
Lastly, Dan sent over the warranty report for systems to David. I put in a request for the renewal budget and should have that no later than mid-week next week, if not sooner.
Please let me know if you have any questions or need anything further.
Have a great weekend and I look forward to seeing you next Wednesday! Erika

Hi Steven,
As a quick follow-up, we would like to continue to have discussions with Powerhouse about security solutions for your organization over time. Our role is to educate our clients on our security stacks so we can create a base layer. I would also like to schedule a Technical Business Review (TBR) with David as we have done in the past. I will speak to David further so we can determine timing.
I am not sure if you have the liberty to maintain a “bucket” in the budget for security layers.

* Endpoint Detection Response (EDR)- Smart Guard
* Security Awareness Training (SAT) – phish testing and training
We have discussed these in the past, except for Smart Guard. This will take time as we want you and David to have clear understanding of any security solutions we would recommend.
Just a thought. I welcome your feedback, Erika

On Fri, Apr 5, 2024 at 8:45 AM Erika Ellis
wrote:
Hi Steven,
Cost Projections as requested:
Additional Users:
Powerhouse contracts supports 60 users.
For 5 additional users to 15 users, the pricing will be $125/user/month with a few caveats:
The $125/user/month is based on the current environment. When we spec out our Total Care services (Managed Services) we consider and incorporate all the hardware that we manage and users as well.
If your equipment remains the same, and you are not adding another 10 switches (as example) we are safe with the $125/user per month
Unless any processes change, I will not uplift or increase the contract for 5 users, it would start at 10 additional.
Security Components:
Managed Detection Response (EDR) with AMTD (Automated Moving Target Defense - see attached
This solution is based on the number of devices – I used 94 devices based on what is in your environment now. If devices go up or down, the pricing will change.
EDR AMTD
94 X $11.50 = $1,081.00 (monthly pricing)
One-Time Setup $999
CAT+ (Phish Testing and Security Awareness Training)
This is based on users – I used 75 below
75 X $3.25 = $243.75 (Monthly pricing)
Setup $999 (One-time setup)
Lastly, Dan sent over the warranty report for systems to David. I put in a request for the renewal budget and should have that no later than mid-week
next week, if not sooner.
Please let me know if you have any questions or need anything further.
Have a great weekend and I look forward to seeing you next Wednesday! Erika

Steven Battaglia (he/him)

direct 718.303.2448
Hi Steven,
Cost Projections as requested:
Additional Users:
* Powerhouse contracts supports 60 users.
* For 5 additional users to 15 users, the pricing will be $125/user/month with a few caveats:
* The $125/user/month is based on the current environment. When we spec out our Total Care services (Managed Services) we consider and incorporate all the hardware that we manage and users as well.
* If your equipment remains the same, and you are not adding another 10 switches (as example) we are safe with the $125/user per month
* Unless any processes change, I will not uplift or increase the contract for 5 users, it would start at 10 additional.
Security Components:
1. Managed Detection Response (EDR) with AMTD (Automated Moving Target Defense - see attached
* This solution is based on the number of devices – I used 94 devices based on what is in your environment now. If devices go up or down, the pricing will change.
EDR AMTD
94 X $11.50 = $1,081.00 (monthly pricing)
One-Time Setup $999
1. CAT+ (Phish Testing and Security Awareness Training)
* This is based on users – I used 75 below
75 X $3.25 = $243.75 (Monthly pricing)
Setup $999 (One-time setup)
Lastly, Dan sent over the warranty report for systems to David. I put in a request for the renewal budget and should have that no later than mid-week next week, if not sooner.
Please let me know if you have any questions or need anything further.
Have a great weekend and I look forward to seeing you next Wednesday! Erika

Hi Steven,
As a quick follow-up, we would like to continue to have discussions with Powerhouse about security solutions for your organization over time. Our role is to educate our clients on our security stacks so we can create a base layer. I would also like to schedule a Technical Business Review (TBR) with David as we have done in the past. I will speak to David further so we can determine timing.
I am not sure if you have the liberty to maintain a “bucket” in the budget for security layers.

* Endpoint Detection Response (EDR)- Smart Guard
* Security Awareness Training (SAT) – phish testing and training
We have discussed these in the past, except for Smart Guard. This will take time as we want you and David to have clear understanding of any security solutions we would recommend.
Just a thought. I welcome your feedback, Erika

I am not sure if you have the liberty to maintain a “bucket” in the budget for security layers.
Just a thought as most of our clients are going in that direction, specifically for:
Endpoint Detection Response (EDR)- Smart Guard
Security Awareness Training (SAT) – phish testing and training
We have discussed these in the past, except for Smart Guard. This will take time as we want you and David to have clear understanding of any security
solutions we would recommend.
Just a thought. I welcome your feedback, Erika

Steven Battaglia (he/him)

direct 718.303.2448
Hi Steven,
Cost Projections as requested:
Additional Users:
* Powerhouse contracts supports 60 users.
* For 5 additional users to 15 users, the pricing will be $125/user/month with a few caveats:
* The $125/user/month is based on the current environment. When we spec out our Total Care services (Managed Services) we consider and incorporate all the hardware that we manage and users as well.
* If your equipment remains the same, and you are not adding another 10 switches (as example) we are safe with the $125/user per month
* Unless any processes change, I will not uplift or increase the contract for 5 users, it would start at 10 additional.
Security Components:
1. Managed Detection Response (EDR) with AMTD (Automated Moving Target Defense - see attached
* This solution is based on the number of devices – I used 94 devices based on what is in your environment now. If devices go up or down, the pricing will change.
EDR AMTD
94 X $11.50 = $1,081.00 (monthly pricing)
One-Time Setup $999
1. CAT+ (Phish Testing and Security Awareness Training)
* This is based on users – I used 75 below
75 X $3.25 = $243.75 (Monthly pricing)
Setup $999 (One-time setup)
Lastly, Dan sent over the warranty report for systems to David. I put in a request for the renewal budget and should have that no later than mid-week next week, if not sooner.
Please let me know if you have any questions or need anything further.
Have a great weekend and I look forward to seeing you next Wednesday! Erika

* Powerhouse contracts supports 60 users.
* For 5 additional users to 15 users, the pricing will be $125/user/month with a few caveats:
* The $125/user/month is based on the current environment. When we spec out our Total Care services (Managed Services) we consider and incorporate all the hardware that we manage and users as well.
* If your equipment remains the same, and you are not adding another 10 switches (as example) we are safe with the $125/user per month
* Unless any processes change, I will not uplift or increase the contract for 5 users, it would start at 10 additional.
Security Components:
1. Managed Detection Response (EDR) with AMTD (Automated Moving Target Defense - see attached
* This solution is based on the number of devices – I used 94 devices based on what is in your environment now. If devices go up or down, the pricing will change.
EDR AMTD
94 X $11.50 = $1,081.00 (monthly pricing)
One-Time Setup $999
1. CAT+ (Phish Testing and Security Awareness Training)
* This is based on users – I used 75 below
75 X $3.25 = $243.75 (Monthly pricing)
Setup $999 (One-time setup)
Lastly, Dan sent over the warranty report for systems to David. I put in a request for the renewal budget and should have that no later than mid-week next week, if not sooner.
Please let me know if you have any questions or need anything further.
Have a great weekend and I look forward to seeing you next Wednesday! Erika

Hi Steven,
As a quick follow-up, we would like to continue to have discussions with Powerhouse about security solutions for your organization over time. Our role is to educate our clients on our security stacks so we can create a base layer. I would also like to schedule a Technical Business Review (TBR) with David as we have done in the past. I will speak to David further so we can determine timing.
I am not sure if you have the liberty to maintain a “bucket” in the budget for security layers.
Just a thought as most of our clients are going in that direction, specifically for:
* Endpoint Detection Response (EDR)- Smart Guard
* Security Awareness Training (SAT) – phish testing and training
We have discussed these in the past, except for Smart Guard. This will take time as we want you and David to have clear understanding of any security solutions we would recommend.
Just a thought. I welcome your feedback, Erika

Additional Users:

* The $125/user/month is based on the current environment. When we spec out our Total Care services (Managed Services) we consider and incorporate all the hardware that we manage and users as well.
* If your equipment remains the same, and you are not adding another 10 switches (as example) we are safe with the $125/user per month
* Unless any processes change, I will not uplift or increase the contract for 5 users, it would start at 10 additional.
Security Components:
1. Managed Detection Response (EDR) with AMTD (Automated Moving Target Defense - see attached
* This solution is based on the number of devices – I used 94 devices based on what is in your environment now. If devices go up or down, the pricing will change.
EDR AMTD
94 X $11.50 = $1,081.00 (monthly pricing)
One-Time Setup $999
1. CAT+ (Phish Testing and Security Awareness Training)
* This is based on users – I used 75 below
75 X $3.25 = $243.75 (Monthly pricing)
Setup $999 (One-time setup)

users as well.

Hi Steven,
As a quick follow-up, we would like to continue to have discussions with Powerhouse about security solutions for your organization over time. Our role is to educate our clients on our security stacks so we can create a base layer. I would also like to schedule a Technical Business Review (TBR) with David as we have done in the past. I will speak to David further so we can determine timing.
I am not sure if you have the liberty to maintain a “bucket” in the budget for security layers.
Just a thought as most of our clients are going in that direction, specifically for:
* Endpoint Detection Response (EDR)- Smart Guard
* Security Awareness Training (SAT) – phish testing and training
We have discussed these in the past, except for Smart Guard. This will take time as we want you and David to have clear understanding of any security solutions we would recommend.
Just a thought. I welcome your feedback, Erika

Hi Steven,
As a quick follow-up, we would like to continue to have discussions with Powerhouse about security solutions for your organization over time. Our role is to educate our clients on our security stacks so we can create a base layer. I would also like to schedule a Technical Business Review (TBR) with David as we have done in the past. * Security Awareness Training (SAT) – phish testing and training
We have discussed these in the past, except for Smart Guard. This will take time as we want you and David to have clear understanding of any security solutions we would recommend.
Just a thought. I welcome your feedback, Erika

On Mon, Nov 13, 2023 at 5:50 PM David Koosis wrote:
Hello Sam:
Awesome news about the launch!
Regarding DNS info, it's a great question. It may be a painless switch, but often there are dependencies which need to be checked to prevent things from breaking.
Hopefully Dan or someone else is familiar with your setup.
Are you using Mailchimp landing pages, or just email? My recollection is that email won't be impacted but landing pages will.
I'd ask the web developers and/or check the hosting service to give you a launch checklist related to network configuration.
Do you know where the site is hosted, and whether you've got it behind a caching or security service, such as Cloudflare?
I'll be in the office tomorrow and happy to jump on a call if I can be helpful.
/dk

Hello Sam:
Awesome news about the launch!
Regarding DNS info, it's a great question. It may be a painless switch, but often there are dependencies which need to be checked to prevent things from breaking.
Hopefully Dan or someone else is familiar with your setup.
Are you using Mailchimp landing pages, or just email? My recollection is that email won't be impacted but landing pages will.
I'd ask the web developers and/or check the hosting service to give you a launch checklist related to network configuration.
Do you know where the site is hosted, and whether you've got it behind a caching or security service, such as Cloudflare?
I'll be in the office tomorrow and happy to jump on a call if I can be helpful.
/dk
Hi Dan,
Hope you're well.
Giving you the heads up that we're planning on launching the new website tomorrow, which means that our web developers will be giving us DNS info to input. Hopefully you'll be able to do this?
Please let me know windows of availability.
Also- will this affect authentication for our MailChimp account?
Thanks,
Sam

Hello Sam:
Awesome news about the launch!
Regarding DNS info, it's a great question. It may be a painless switch, but often there are dependencies which need to be checked to prevent things from breaking.
Hopefully Dan or someone else is familiar with your setup.
Are you using Mailchimp landing pages, or just email? My recollection is that email won't be impacted but landing pages will.
I'd ask the web developers and/or check the hosting service to give you a launch checklist related to network configuration.
Do you know where the site is hosted, and whether you've got it behind a caching or security service, such as Cloudflare?

Hello Sam:
Awesome news about the launch!
Regarding DNS info, it's a great question. It may be a painless switch, but
often there are dependencies which need to be checked to prevent things
from breaking.
Hopefully Dan or someone else is familiar with your setup.
Are you using Mailchimp landing pages, or just email? My recollection is
that email won't be impacted but landing pages will.
I'd ask the web developers and/or check the hosting service to give you a
launch checklist related to network configuration.
Do you know where the site is hosted, and whether you've got it behind a
caching or security service, such as Cloudflare?

helpful.

From: Erika Ellis <EEllis@thetnsgroup.com>
To: David Koosis <vcto@powerhousearts.org>
Date: 2024-01-09 21:01:44
Subject: RE: following up

Hi David,
First, thank you for your candid response – I truly appreciate the open communication.
Our clients are of our utmost importance. My apologies that our discussion came across as a disappointment. I looked at the discussion a little differently, but regardless, your perception is what matters.
We are a committed partner to Powerhouse and want to do all that we can to move things forward. We just want to make sure that our clients have the parameters as to what we are capable and what we are not. Perhaps we overstated that. During the call Rob stated that we can take it on and outlined that we can monitor the device for connectivity and provide OS upgrades for security purposes. I thought we agreed on this but should have closed the loop.
Rob, Steve, and I jumped on a call when I got your email. We all agreed that all your bullet points are correct, and things that we can do from a service standpoint. If you still want TNS to spec out the device, we will go ahead and do so unless you prefer to do so on your side. Just let me know and I will stop the process internally.
In terms of “the open to the IIS” – can you provide more details on this? We manage/”own” the network and always want Powerhouse to ensure the security of it. We need to reinforce the importance of any 3rd party vendors that want to make changes on the network to go through TNS (always copy Rob and myself). That way we can assess the situation and provide the pros/cons from a security perspective so Powerhouse can make a business decision if you agree. I was going to put this on our agenda for our monthly meeting.
Lastly, in terms of your taking on the initiative to determine where the lines are between vendors, we appreciate it. Our intent was to provide those lines in these types of situations, while sharing what we can do.
Again, thank you for your feedback so we can continue to strengthen our partnership. I am available tomorrow if you want to jump on a call.
Warm regards, Erika
Erika Ellis
O: 212-967-5757 option 2
EEllis@thetnsgroup.com

From: David Koosis
Sent: Tuesday, January 9, 2024 3:02 PM
To: Erika Ellis
Subject: following up
EXTERNAL EMAIL!!!
Hi Erika!
Because it's best for our partnership if I am direct and transparent, I'll tell you I was disappointed with our conversation.
Instead of offering solutions or telling me that server management is not something you provide, you explained the challenges of being a managed service provider.
I understand the constraints and concerns you referenced, and I've worked through these kinds of issues lots of times, as I thought you guys had too.
I was expecting your response when you called might have been something like:
David:
* We don't work with NUC's much, but we're very familiar with Dell 1Us. Since you said equivalent specs would be fine, we propose a Dell 1U, which costs a little more -- $xxx -- and works well with our management tools.
* Our server management service costs XXX and includes keeping the OS and firmware patched at a level recommended by Microsoft to protect against critical level security issues.
* We can also keep some other common software -- like web servers -- up-to-date if you choose.
* If application software running on the server requires specific conditions -- such as ports which must be open, or software systems which should NOT be patched, we can usually respect those requirements.
* We can monitor the health of the server and its network connectivity.
* HOWEVER: We can not be responsible for the proper functioning of application software running on the server.
* In order to make this work, we need to agree on a protocol for triaging and handling issues that come up.
In general, we can provide a server healthcheck at any time by checking the dashboard or XXXX. If the server healthcheck shows that the server is running and reachable on the network, then PHA must route any problems using the application to the application software vendor. We can refine this protocol collaboratively.
---
I am on your side, working to have TNS valued as a highly skilled strategic partner. I hope you understand my feedback and have the support you need internally to improve our future conversations.
Let me know if this makes sense to you, or if we're seeing things differently.
Thank you
/dk
--
David Koosis (he/him)
v Chief Technology Officer (consultant)
Powerhouse Arts / Tue-Thu
direct 646.481.4141

Hi David,
First, thank you for your candid response – I truly appreciate the open communication.
Our clients are of our utmost importance. My apologies that our discussion came across as a disappointment. I looked at the discussion a little differently, but regardless, your perception is what matters.
We are a committed partner to Powerhouse and want to do all that we can to move things forward. We just want to make sure that our clients have the parameters as to what we are capable and what we are not. Perhaps we overstated that.
During the call Rob stated that we can take it on and outlined that we can monitor the device for connectivity and provide OS upgrades for security purposes. I thought we agreed on this but should have closed the loop.
Rob, Steve, and I jumped on a call when I got your email. We all agreed that all your bullet points are correct, and things that we can do from a service standpoint. If you still want TNS to spec out the device, we will go ahead and
do so unless you prefer to do so on your side. Just let me know and I will stop the process internally.
In terms of “the open to the IIS” – can you provide more details on this? We manage/”own” the network and always want Powerhouse to ensure the security of it. We need to reinforce the importance of any 3 rd party vendors that
want to make changes on the network to go through TNS (always copy Rob and myself). That way we can assess the situation and provide the pros/cons from a security perspective so Powerhouse can make a business decision if you agree. I was going to put this
on our agenda for our monthly meeting.
Lastly, in terms of your taking on the initiative to determine where the lines are between vendors, we appreciate it. Our intent was to provide those lines in these types of situations, while sharing what we can do.
Again, thank you for your feedback so we can continue to strengthen our partnership. I am available tomorrow if you want to jump on a call.
Warm regards, Erika
Erika Ellis

To: Erika Ellis
Hi Erika!
Because it's best for our partnership if I am direct and transparent, I'll
tell you I was disappointed with our conversation.
Instead of offering solutions or telling me that server management is not
something you provide, you explained the challenges of being a managed
service provider.
I understand the constraints and concerns you referenced, and I've worked
through these kinds of issues lots of times, as I thought you guys had too.
I was expecting your response when you called might have been something
like:
David:
- We don't work with NUC's much, but we're very familiar with Dell 1Us.
Since you said equivalent specs would be fine, we propose a Dell 1U, which
costs a little more -- $xxx -- and works well with our management tools.
- Our server management service costs XXX and includes keeping the OS
and firmware patched at a level recommended by Microsoft to protect against
critical level security issues.
- We can also keep some other common software -- like web servers --
up-to-date if you choose.
- If application software running on the server requires specific
conditions -- such as ports which must be open, or software systems which
should NOT be patched, we can usually respect those requirements.
- We can monitor the health of the server and its network connectivity.
- HOWEVER: We can not be responsible for the proper functioning of
application software running on the server.
- In order to make this work, we need to agree on a protocol for
triaging and handling issues that come up.
In general, we can provide a server healthcheck at any time by checking
the dashboard or XXXX. If the server healthcheck shows that the server is
running and reachable on the network, then PHA must route any problems
using the application to the application software vendor. We can refine
this protocol collaboratively.
---
I am on your side, working to have TNS valued as a highly skilled strategic
partner. I hope you understand my feedback and have the support you need
internally to improve our future conversations.
Let me know if this makes sense to you, or if we're seeing things
differently.
Thank you
/dk

*Request*
Configure Arternal with Third-Part App access on Powerhouse Google
Workspace.
These are the directions from Arternal:
https://intercom.help/arternal/en/articles/5812133-linking-google-email-accounts
This is time sensitive, due by Tue Nov 14 -- earlier would be terrific. If
that's not possible, please alert me. Thank you!
*Background*
Powerhouse has signed up with Arternal, a SaaS provider for art sales. To
support integrated email (and some other capabilities?) Arternal requested
access rights.
*Additional Points of Contact*
Powerhouse customer and point-of-contact for Arternal is: Megan Skidmore (
megan@powerhousearts.org)
Arternal point-of-contact (non-technical): Georgieanna Richer (
georgeianna@arternal.com)
*Notes*
Follow your standard protocol for these kinds of admin changes to Google
Workspace, as far as any logging or permissions.
When you configure, please check if Arternal is requiring any "sensitive"
or "restricted" Google API Oauth scopes, and whether access can be
restricted to named Powerhouse accounts.
Thank you

From: David Koosis <vcto@powerhousearts.org>
To: support@thetnsgroup.com
Date: 2023-11-09 10:45:44
Subject: Google Workspace administration - configure Arternal access

*Request*
Configure Arternal with Third-Part App access on Powerhouse Google
Workspace.
These are the directions from Arternal:
https://intercom.help/arternal/en/articles/5812133-linking-google-email-accounts
This is time sensitive, due by Tue Nov 14 -- earlier would be terrific. If
that's not possible, please alert me. Thank you!
*Background*
Powerhouse has signed up with Arternal, a SaaS provider for art sales. To
support integrated email (and some other capabilities?) Arternal requested
access rights.
*Additional Points of Contact*
Powerhouse customer and point-of-contact for Arternal is: Megan Skidmore (
megan@powerhousearts.org)
Arternal point-of-contact (non-technical): Georgieanna Richer (
georgeianna@arternal.com)
*Notes*
Follow your standard protocol for these kinds of admin changes to Google
Workspace, as far as any logging or permissions.
When you configure, please check if Arternal is requiring any "sensitive"
or "restricted" Google API Oauth scopes, and whether access can be
restricted to named Powerhouse accounts.
Thank you
